title: SCSU football: SCSU stomps Minnesota-Crookston
text:
SCSU football: SCSU stomps Minnesota-Crookston MITCHELL HANSEN, mhansen@stcloudtimes.com 6:33 p.m. CDT October 3, 2015 Buy Photo St. Cloud State's Nate Meyer runs with the ball during Saturday's game between St. Cloud State and Minnesota-Crookston at Husky Stadium in St. Cloud. (Photo: Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com) Buy Photo 
It was all St. Cloud State on Saturday afternoon at Husky Stadium. 
The Huskies exploded for 555 total yards on offense in a 62-14 NSIC college football win over Minnesota-Crookston. 
St. Cloud State finished with 309 yards passing and 246 yards rushing in the win. 
The Huskies jumped out to a 41-0 lead at halftime, led by running back Jaden Huff and quarterback Nate Meyer. 
Huff scored the first two touchdowns in the game for the Huskies. He ran for 37 yards on the day. 
Meyer threw three touchdowns and ran for another to end the opening half. The Rocori graduate finished 14-for-19 with 280 yards passing and 79 yards rushing.

Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
“Everybody did their jobs and we played well,” Meyer said. “It’s nice to get two wins in a row here and we want to keep this going into the North Conference play.” 
Wide receiver Jameson Parsons had 133 yards receiving and two touchdowns and tight end Grant Thayer caught for 104 yards and one touchdown. 
“We’ve had trouble in the past with execution and we wanted to work on that today,” Parsons said. “(Meyer and I) have been working on timing and we are on the same page lately and it has been working out well for us.” 
St. Cloud State coach Scott Underwood wanted his team to go out and play hard the whole game, regardless of the score. He certainly got that. 
“That was our biggest thing, because we have not done that yet this year,” Underwood said. “I thought at times we executed at a high level and I’m really proud of our guys and the way that they played today.” 
Lost in the offensive outburst was the fact that St. Cloud State (3-2 NSIC, 3-2 overall) held Minnesota-Crookston (0-5, 0-5) to 226 total yards on the day, including holding the Golden Eagles to 60 total yards in the first half. 
Story continues below. Buy Photo 
St. Cloud State's Jake Schley celebrates a big defensive play during Saturday's game between St. Cloud State and Minnesota-Crookston at Husky Stadium in St. Cloud. (Photo: Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com) 
Defensive back Brady Westart and linebacker Adam Josephson each led the Huskies with six tackles. 
“From the first snap to the last, we played out hardest. We knew that if we played hard, we will come out with a win,” Westart said. “It was a good team win overall.” 
Next up for the Huskies is Minnesota-Duluth at 1:05 p.m. Saturday in Duluth. It the Bulldogs’ homecoming. 
“It should be a good game. It’s always a battle with them,” Meyer said. “It will be a great atmosphere up there as always.” 
Notes 
• Sophomore quarterback McKinley Anderson took over for Meyer in the third quarter and finished 4-for-5 with 29 yards and one touchdown passing. He also ran for 33 yards in the game. 
• Redshirt freshman running back Curtwan Evans ran for 46 yards and one touchdown for SCSU. 
• Minnesota-Crookston sophomore quarterback Tra Hearns went 12-for-24 with 127 yards and two touchdowns for the Golden Eagles.

Team statistics 
First downs: UMC 14, SCSU 28; Rushes-yards: UMC 33-99, SCSU 45-246; Passing yards: UMC 127, SCSU 309; Punts-avg: UMC 9-37.3, SCSU 2-35; Fumbles-lost: UMC 0-0, SCSU 0-0; Penalties-yards: UMC 8-51, SCSU 5-41; Time of possession: UMC 30:27, SCSU 29:28; Sacks-yards: UMC 2-13, SCSU 5-33; Interceptions: none. 
UMC: 0-5 NSIC, 0-5 overall. Up next: vs. Bemidji State, 1 p.m. Saturday in Crookston. 
St. Cloud State: 3-2 NSIC, 3-2 overall. Up next: at Minnesota-Duluth, 1:05 p.m. Saturday in Duluth.
